content: The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" may be cited as the short title. Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines key terms such as "Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material," "design-basis threat," and "formula quantities of strategic special nuclear material." The term "Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty" refers to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, while a "nuclear weapon" is defined as any device utilizing atomic energy for use as a weapon. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty refers to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, while a nuclear weapon is any device utilizing atomic energy for use as a weapon. SEC. 3. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the threat of terrorists acquiring and using a nuclear weapon is urgent and poses a significant risk to national and global security. Efforts to secure, monitor, and reduce nuclear stockpiles have made progress, but more actions are necessary to minimize the risk of nuclear terrorism. The White House's 2006 National Strategy for Combating Terrorism highlights the grave threat of weapons of mass destruction in the hands of terrorists. United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan has also warned about the catastrophic impact of a nuclear terror attack. United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan has emphasized the devastating impact of a nuclear terror attack, stating it would cause widespread death, destruction, and economic turmoil. UN Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) underscores the importance of preventing non-state actors from acquiring and using nuclear, chemical, or biological weapons. The Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Dr. Mohammed El Baradei, has highlighted the urgency to prevent a terrorist attack involving nuclear weapons, emphasizing the need to prohibit the development, transportation, and use of such weapons for terrorist purposes. The Sense of Congress emphasizes the prevention of nuclear terrorism. The Sense of Congress emphasizes the prevention of nuclear terrorism by taking a comprehensive approach to reduce the threat, including efforts to eliminate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons and secure nuclear materials worldwide. The Sense of Congress emphasizes the prevention of nuclear terrorism by taking a comprehensive approach to reduce the threat, including efforts to secure all nuclear weapons and strategic special nuclear material worldwide. The President should prioritize preventing a nuclear terrorist attack on the United States and accelerate programs to combat nuclear smuggling and secure nuclear materials globally, with support for the International Atomic Energy Agency's role in coordinating international efforts. The legislation sponsored by Senator Richard Lugar, Senator Pete Domenici, and former Senator Sam Nunn has led to groundbreaking programs to prevent nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of terrorists. SEC. 5. SENIOR ADVISOR TO THE PRESIDENT FOR THE PREVENTION OF NUCLEAR TERRORISM. An amendment to the National Security Act of 1947 establishes a senior advisor to the president for the prevention of nuclear terrorism. The National Security Act of 1947 establishes a Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Advisor's duties include advising the President on nuclear terrorism matters and formulating US policies to prevent nuclear terrorism by developing plans and addressing program inefficiencies. The Senior Advisor to the President is responsible for overseeing the development of accelerated program implementation strategies, budget requests, and new initiatives to prevent nuclear terrorism. They also coordinate US efforts to implement these policies and may appoint necessary personnel to assist in their duties. The Senior Advisor to the President may appoint and terminate necessary personnel to perform duties related to preventing nuclear terrorism. Additionally, the Senior Advisor is designated as a member of the National Security Council. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism may appoint personnel and is a member of the National Security Council. An annual report is required. The President must submit an annual report to Congress on the security of strategic special nuclear material, including a survey of facilities worldwide containing nuclear weapons and materials. The President's annual report to Congress includes a list of facilities worldwide containing nuclear weapons and materials, prioritizing sites for removal or security based on theft risk. A plan is outlined for securing or removing nuclear weapons and materials. The President's annual report to Congress includes a plan for securing or removing nuclear weapons, strategic special nuclear material, and radiological materials at vulnerable facilities worldwide. The report also covers efforts to establish security standards and related policies. The report may be submitted in classified form but must include a detailed unclassified summary. SEC. 7 outlines the minimum security standard for nuclear weapons and strategic special nuclear materials. The policy of the United States is to ensure the security and accountability of all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials. In line with international standards, the President will work towards a global agreement on nuclear security to effectively protect these materials. The United States policy aims to ensure nuclear security by protecting weapons and special nuclear materials from terrorists and criminals, considering equipment and human limitations, and implementing verifiable measures. The President will collaborate with other countries and the International Atomic Energy Agency to upgrade security standards globally. The United States aims to upgrade nuclear security globally by ensuring effective rules and enforcement for all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials, with financial and technical assistance provided to accelerate security upgrades in countries needing support. The United States aims to enhance global nuclear security by implementing effective regulations and enforcement for all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials worldwide, including the use of a regulatory design-basis threat model to counter threats from terrorists and criminals. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2008 totaling $50,000,000 to increase international participation in converting nuclear facilities from highly enriched uranium to low enriched uranium and to remove highly enriched uranium from such facilities.
